   GLAROS, AG
TI SELF-CONTROL OF STRESS-INDUCED CARDIOVASCULAR CHANGE USING TRANSIT-TIME
   FEEDBACK
SO PSYCHOPHYSIOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
AB Normotensive subjects (48) underwent 1 of 4 training conditions: transit time plus stress (TTPS), transit time minus stress (TTMS), false feedback plus stress (FF) and a stress only control (C). In the 1st session, all subjects received an arithmetic stressor but without training. In the 2nd and 3rd sessions, subjects received training appropriate to their conditions. The TTPS and FF groups received arithmetic stressors prior to the transit time trainig, whereas the TTMS group rested prior to training. Training in the TTPS and TTMS groups consisted of beat-to-beat pulse transit time feedback. During the training period, the FF group received bogus feedback. In the 4th session, all subjects received the stressor followed by instructions to lower blood pressure (increase transit time). No feedback was available. Significant transit time decreases occurred in response to the stress in all groups during the 1st session. In the 4th session, the TTPS group showed virtually no transit time decrease during the stressor, while the remaining 3 groups continued to show significant transit time decreases to the stressor. Self control over the subjects'' reactivity to the arithmetic stressor had occurred in the transit time plus stress group. This effect did not appear to be due solely to either repeated exposure to the stressor or to learned control via feedback training. The effect seemed to result from the combination of exposure and training.
C1 WAYNE STATE UNIV, DETROIT, MI 48202 USA.

TI EVENT-RELATED POTENTIALS TO A CHANGE OF PACE IN A VISUAL SEQUENCE
SO PSYCHOPHYSIOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
AB Visual event-related potentials (ERP) were recorded from 11 subjects (human) presented with a sequence of brief flashes occurring at a regular interstimulus interval (ISI) of 1200 ms. Occasionally and unpredictably a flash occurred early: 450, 375 or 300 ms after the previous flash. On one run, subjects responded with a button press to the early flashes; on the other, they listened to a story presented over headphones and the flashes were not task relevant. Two distinct negativities (N1 and N2) were elicited, and each was affected by a combination of task and stimulus variables. The amplitude of N1 (143 ms), appearing at the vertex and occiput, was affected by event probability as well as the ISI and task relevance of the early flashes. The N2 (230 ms) to the visual pace change was dependent on attention and was relatively unaffected by further shortening of ISI. The P3 was larger to the early than regular flashes and was greatly affected by the task relevance of the early flashes.
C1 STANFORD UNIV, MED CTR, SCH MED, DEPT PSYCHIAT & BEHAV SCI, STANFORD, CA 94305 USA.
C3 Stanford University
RP VET ADM MED CTR, PALO ALTO, CA 94304 USA.

   CAPRIOTTI, R
TI AUTONOMIC NERVOUS-SYSTEM FUNCTION AND AGING - RESPONSE SPECIFICITY
SO PSYCHOPHYSIOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
AB Age differences in autonomic nervous sytem response patterns were investigated to determine if there was an age-related increase in the tendency to respond to multiple stimuli with a consistent response hierarchy (individual consistency). Five stimuli were administered in a Latin Square design: mental arithmetic, cold pressor, isometric exercise, comic slide and time estimation. A warning tone was presented before each stimulus. Physiological measures included heart rate, systolic and diastolic blood pressures, skin potential, breathing rate and digital blood flow. To compare responses in different systems, responses were standardized. A matrix was generated for each subject. Intraclass correlations were then computed. Individual consistency significantly increased with increasing age (r = 0.33, P < 0.005).

   LANG, PJ
TI CORRECTING BASELINE DRIFT ARTIFACT IN SLOW POTENTIAL RECORDING
SO PSYCHOPHYSIOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
AB A problem frequently encountered by investigators measuring [human] scalp-recorded DC potentials is baseline drift artifact. The sources of baseline drift are many, and it is often difficult to remove drift from the primary data. The problem is particularly acute when long recording epochs are under investigation. A software solution using a FORTRAN IV computer program which defines drift as a significant linear trend in prestimulus voltage on successive experimental trials, is proposed. When drift is determined to be present, its slope is computed and statistically removed from the data in the poststimulus (response) period. A sample data set is included, which demonstrates the method''s marked improvement of signal-to-noise ratios, as represented by reduced error variance and improved statistical discrimination between the independent variables of an experiment.

   FOWLES, DC
TI MAGNITUDE OF INCENTIVE EFFECTS ON HEART-RATE
SO PSYCHOPHYSIOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
AB Previous demonstrations of monetary incentive effects on heart rate during a continuous motor task were extended by employing different magnitudes of monetary incentive. The influence of the total amount of monetary incentive for the experiment was examined by providing monetary incentives either for only 2 trials or for all 5 trials. This procedure also provided an evaluation of the effect on heart rate during the later trials of discontinuing the incentive after 2 trials. A clear and graded effect of the amount of incentive per response was shown, but no significant effects were obtained for the total amount of incentive, in spite of providing subjects with clear feedback as to how much money they could expect. Discontinuing incentives produced a significant decrease in heart rate, compared to subjects who continued to receive incentives. No effect was found for the magnitude of incentive on the rate of responding on the motor task, rendering unlikely an explanation for the results in terms of cardiac-somatic coupling. Also, any possible contribution to the heart rate results from frustrative nonreward feedback was eliminated by avoiding any suggestion of failure feedback on the task. The effects are attributable to the incentive value of the monetary reward and that they are large enough to be of considerable interest.

   NIRNBERGER, G

   NIRNBERGER, G
TI CONCEPT-IDENTIFICATION AS A FUNCTION OF PRECEDING NEGATIVE OR POSITIVE
   SPONTANEOUS SHIFTS IN SLOW BRAIN POTENTIALS
SO PSYCHOPHYSIOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
AB The stimuli of a concept identification experiment (20) were presented to humans such that each stimulus was preceded by either a negative or a positive spontaneous slow potential shift in the EEG (C3 to mastoid). The stimuli were presented visually for 4 s. The subject''s task was to learn a concept consisting of 1 vertical and 1 slanted line. He or she responded by pressing a key within 2 s after stimulus offset to indicate whether the stimulus belonged to the concept or not, with immediate feedback. Slow potential shifts were automatically detected by a computer and were used to trigger the stimuli. The concept was learned significantly faster when the stimulus was preceded by a negative shift (minimum of -25 .mu.V) than when it was preceded by a positive shift (minimum of +25 .mu.V).

PT J
AU BENSHAKHAR, G
AF BENSHAKHAR, G
TI HABITUATION OF THE ORIENTING RESPONSE TO COMPLEX SEQUENCES OF STIMULI
SO PSYCHOPHYSIOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
AB Habituation of the electrodermal component of the orienting response to complex sequences of stimuli, i.e., sequences of at least 2 different recurring stimuli, was studied. From the simple habituation curve to 1 stimulus, 3 alternative models are suggested to predict the response to that same stimulus in a given trial of the complex sequence. The study was carried out in 2 stages. In experiment (exp) 1, simple habituation curves were constructed for 2 types of stimuli (chosen and non-chosen). The results of this exp provided 2 negative exponential functions fitted to the data of 101 [human] subjects. Exp 2 and 3 were designed to compare the models and used complex sequences of chosen and non-chosen stimuli in different mixtures. The prediction of each model was correlated with the actual data of 120 subjects in exp 2 and 160 subjects in exp 3. The 2 experiments produced a similar picture regarding the relative validities of the 3 models. The 2 models that assume independent habituation processes of the 2 stimuli comprising the sequence fitted the data better than a model that assumes complete generalization of habituation. Sokolov''s theory was discussed. Theoretical and methodological implications of the models were mentioned, and several suggestions for further research and formulation of more complex models were proposed.
C1 HEBREW UNIV JERUSALEM, DEPT PSYCHOL, JERUSALEM 91000, ISRAEL.
